data.text: Recumbent Bike Seats are Comfortable for Long Distance Travelling

There's been some discussions about comfortable seats for riding so I thought it might be useful to some to raise a bit of awareness about recumbent bikes. I've been riding this beauty for last month, I did somewhere around 1600 km over different terrains (smooth and very bumpy) and I had zero pain in my butt, back, neck, wrists or any part of the body. Of course this kind of bike is not for every occasion but it's extremely comfortable and well suited for long distance travelling :) IG: @cycle.around https://instagram.com/cycle.around
I swear to Great Scott another one uncomfy saddle and I will switch to that beauty
data.author: Tomasz Plasota

data.text: yep, my motivation was basically the same. I didn't want to test 10 saddles on the way and hope to find the good one so I opted for sofa. :D

data.text: hey Jimmy, right now I can do 10% climbs but I think when I train my legs a bit more I'll be able to do 12% as well. Of course the front gets lighter but I weight 80 kg as well so it puts some weight on the front as well. :)

data.text: I own 20 year old recumbent (vision r40 uss) and a Cruzbike q45 I haven’t decided which would be a better touring platform, love them both. I feel a Little more comfortable on my Vision. Anyway bottom line no sore or numb wrists,neck or butt I wish i would have made the switch years ago.
data.author: Steve Lynch

data.text: what wheel set/brakes on your q45? My two bents are a vision r40 oss and a q45 with discs and spacing for wider tires- my last tour was on the q with some heavy duty 26x2s, allowed it to handle the heavy load and unpredictable roads well. I generally associate my vision with a road racing bike, it sits on ~25mm tires and doesn't have nearly the cargo capacity.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: I’m running the stock 1.65’s with tekto cable Disks. What gearing are you using? And your bags look like a great fit what brand? My Ortliebs not so compatible with this factory rack, I just leave them on my R 40.
data.author: Steve Lynch

data.text: I think I just read the post on your q45 specs.
data.author: Steve Lynch

data.text: it was definitely a lot of trial and error getting bags to work right (maybe I was just unlucky with the selection of bags I own).
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: I did find used fenders in a bicycle warehouse. Had to modify them they fit the 1.65’s well but if got any fatter might Be a problem.
data.author: Steve Lynch

data.text: I get antsy watching this knowing I could never stand up and crank. Standing and cranking is the best antidote to all the pains you're talking about. Also riding with no hands (why I put almost no weight on my fork) I can see this being counter productive to your health if you don't absolutely need it. Just one riding position. That said, I've never tried it! I'd love a test ride

data.text: Does riding recumbent make climbs any harder?

data.text: hey Nick, yeah, it's harder to cycle uphill since you cannot step into the pedals and use your gravitational force but only your muscles. :)

data.text: Any difficulties with balance getting moving from a standstill or whilst riding?
data.author: Gareth Stephens

data.text: I started riding a recumbent this spring for the first time. Getting rolling from a stop took some practice. I learned to push off really hard on the first pedal stroke, and keep pedaling til I was going. After that, it rides fine. Balance is just like any bike, and the recumbent is considerably more comfortable.
data.author: Gary Brown

data.text: hey, it takes few days to getting to it, but after that it feels really natural as anything else. Our brains are pretty good at learning new things. :)
data.author: Jirka Beran

data.text: they are way less stable. Can be hard to start, almost impossible uphill.
data.author: Rich Langston

data.text: I think it depends a lot on gearing. I can start uphill around 5-6% climbs, but of course 10% is virtually impossible with my load.

data.text: I gave it a try when I had hip problems. After my replacement, went back to regular and don’t miss anything except the view.

data.text: Agh Gh, cappin …. Ye may well be a trendsetter yet

data.text: thanks a lot :) I've seen a guy who did 160 000 km on this exact model, so I have some confidence. :)
data.author: Jirka Beran

data.text: It seems awkward and more tiring as you aren’t using gravity to move the pedals. Please let me know if I am incorrect
data.author: Christine Gibbons Nigida

data.text: if you're using clipless pedals (which is generally how you ride a recumbent, it's harder to keep your feet up on the pedals otherwise), gravity has little to do with pedal stroke, as opposed to using your leg muscles to turn even circles. Only exception to that is the lack of ability to stand and pedal- but you can mimic it somewhat by bracing yourself on the seat and handles to shove against the pedals. The comfort of the seat/seated position and aerodynamic advantages make up for it.

data.text: In the early days of internet blogs and wireless internet, 1999-2001ish I read Dutchman Ben Treins travelogue whilst he pedalled around the world on a recumbant. The blog doesn't exist anymore but it was very, very good - uploading images and stories as he went along, something we take for granted now.

data.text: Cool videos! I just did my last tour on this thing, and yeah, it makes most of the time a breeze.
